multiple_choice.body: Suppose that the correlation r between two quantitative variables was found to be r = 0. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this correlation value?

input.choice: There is a strong linear relationship between the two variables.
There is no linear relationship between the two variables.
There is a strong relationship between the two variables.
There is no relationship between the two variables.

response.feedback: Incorrect. A correlation coefficient far from zero would indicate a strong linear relationship.

Correct. The correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the linearity of a scatterplot relationship, and a correlation coefficient that is zero indicates no linear relationship. However, that there might still be some other (non-straight-line) kind of relationship.
Incorrect. A correlation coefficient far from zero would indicate a strong linear relationship.
Not quite right. The correlation coefficient only measures linear relationship.

multiple_choice.body: The data in the scatterplot below are an individual's weight and the time it takes (in seconds) on a treadmill to raise his or her pulse rate to 140 beats per minute. The o's correspond to females and the +'s to males. Which of the following conclusions is most accurate?

input.choice: There is a positive correlation between gender and weight.
There is a negative correlation between time and weight for males and for females.
There is a positive correlation between time and weight for males and for females.
There is a negative correlation between gender and weight.

response.feedback: Incorrect. There can only be a correlation between two quantitative variables. But notice that "gender" is categorical. Also, the correlation coefficient would be positive only when the points tend to rise from left to right.

Correct. For each separate gender, we see that the points on the scatterplot tend to fall from left to right. This indicates a negative relationship. So the correlation coefficient would be negative for males, and would also be negative for females.

Incorrect. The correlation coefficient would be positive only when the points tend to rise from left to right. But on the scatterplot, we see that, for both males and females, the points tend to fall from left to right.
Incorrect. The scatterplot does show a negative correlation pattern, but there can only be a correlation between two quantitative variables. But notice that "gender" is categorical.

multiple_choice.body: What can we say about the relationship between the correlation r and the slope b of the least-squares line for the same set of data?

input.choice: Both r and b always have values between −1 and 1.
r is always larger than b.
r and b have the same sign (+ or −).
The slope b is always equal to the square of the correlation r.
b is always larger than r.

response.feedback: Incorrect. It’s true that the correlation r always has a value between −1 and 1, but there is no such restriction on slope. The slope of a line can exceed 1 or −1.
Incorrect. Remember that the correlation r always has value between −1 and 1, but a regression line could have a slope larger than 1. So it’s possible for b to be larger than r.
Correct. Although the correlation r isn’t the same as the slope b, the thing they always have in common is their sign.

Incorrect. There is no such relationship between slope and correlation. Remember that the correlation r always has a value between 0 and 1, so the square of the correlation will also be between −1 and 1. But there is no such restriction on slope.

Incorrect. Remember that for points that tend to rise from left to right, the correlation is close to 1 when the points are tightly clustered around the regression line. But if the regression line is shallow, the slope could be close to zero. So it’s possible for b to be less than r.

multiple_choice.body: If there is no relationship (linear or otherwise) between two quantitative variables as observed on a scatterplot, the value of the correlation coefficient, r, is likely to be which of the following?

input.choice: Closer to 1
Closer to −1
Closer to 0
Either closer to −1 or 1

response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that a correlation close to 1 indicates a strong positive relationship.
Incorrect. Recall that a correlation close to −1 indicates a strong negative relationship.
Correct. A correlation value close to 0 indicates no relationship between two quantitative variables.
Incorrect. Recall correlation close to 1 or −1 indicates reasonably strong positive or negative relationships, respectively.

multiple_choice.body: Using data from 100 hospitals, a correlation of r = 0.78 is found between the size of a hospital (measured in number of beds) and the average length of patient stays (measured in days). Which of the following is true?

input.choice: There is a pretty strong positive linear correlation between number of beds and length of hospital stay.
Increasing hospital size must be the cause of longer patient stays.
“Severity of illness” is a possible lurking variable that is behind this relationship.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The correlation coefficient by itself isn’t enough to determine whether the relationship was linear. You would need to look at the scatterplot to determine if the relationship was a straight-line trend.

Incorrect. You can’t determine causation merely from the nature of a display. Just because there might be an association, that doesn’t (by itself) indicate anything about causation. Causation can only be determined by knowing the nature of the study design.

Correct. Severity of illness is a possible lurking variable, since the seriousness of a patient’s condition is will determine the length of stay. Also, since larger hospitals are more likely to treat severe conditions, this would explain why the patient stays are longer for large hospitals.

multiple_choice.body: The data in the scatterplot below are an individual's age (in years) and the expected life span (in years). The circles correspond to females and the x's to males. Which of the following conclusions is most accurate?

input.choice: There is a positive correlation between gender and life expectancy.
There is a negative correlation between gender and life expectancy.
There is a positive correlation between age and life expectancy for both males and females.
There is a negative correlation between age and life expectancy for both males and females.

response.feedback: Incorrect. There can only be a "correlation" between two quantitative variables. But notice that "gender" is categorical. Also, the correlation coefficient would be positive only when the points tend to rise from left to right.
Incorrect. The scatterplot does show a negative correlation pattern, but there can only be a "correlation" between two quantitative variables. But notice that "gender" is categorical.

Incorrect. The correlation coefficient would be positive only when the points tend to rise from left to right. But on the scatterplot, we see that, for both males and females, the points tend to fall from left to right.

Correct. For each separate gender, we see that the points on the scatterplot tend to fall from left to right. This indicates a negative relationship. So the correlation coefficient would be negative for males, and would also be negative for females.

multiple_choice.body: Suppose the correlation between two variables (x, y) in a data set is determined to be r = 0.63, What must be true about the slope, b, of the least-squares line estimated for the same set of data?

input.choice: The slope will also be a value between −1 and 1.
The slope will have the opposite sign as the correlation.
The slope b is always equal to the square of the correlation r.
The slope will have the same sign as the correlation.

response.feedback: Incorrect. It’s true that the correlation r always has a value between −1 and 1. But there is no such restriction on slope. The slope of a line can exceed 1 or be less than −1.
Incorrect. A line’s slope indicates if the points rise from left to right or fall from left to right, the same as correlation.

Incorrect. There is no such relationship between slope and correlation. Remember that the correlation r always has a value between −1 and 1, so the square of the correlation will be between 0 and 1. But there is no such restriction on slope.

Correct. The slope, b, will always have the same sign as the correlation coefficient, r. Lines with positive slope tend to rise left to right, just like points that are positively associated. Lines with negative slope tend to fall left to right, just like points that are negatively associated.
